text: For tracking the "customerStrategyRef" argument when placing an order is totally sufficient. Though it's limited to 16 chars i think so you will want to keep it in mind when generating these references (e.g I would encode my strategy parameters into a hash and keep the mapping somewhere so I can easily reverse the hash and figure out which params are responsible for the order. )

elements.text: For tracking the "customerStrategyRef" argument when placing an order is totally sufficient. Though it's limited to 16 chars i think so you will want to keep it in mind when generating these references (e.g I would encode my strategy parameters into a hash and keep the mapping somewhere so I can easily reverse the hash and figure out which params are responsible for the order. )

text: I think <@U013Z24LD0U> is thinking about how to track the absolute performance of a strategy over time rather than the individual bets so that he can scale automatically according to performance (or something like that). For that he needs to keep some sort of overall record and write it out to a file.

elements.text: I think

is thinking about how to track the absolute performance of a strategy over time rather than the individual bets so that he can scale automatically according to performance (or something like that). For that he needs to keep some sort of overall record and write it out to a file.

text: Me either. I've been functioning on two accounts for ever and just switched over to MSA recently. I wouldn't use it just to differentiate strategies, not worth the bother.

elements.text: Me either. I've been functioning on two accounts for ever and just switched over to MSA recently. I wouldn't use it just to differentiate strategies, not worth the bother.

text: Yeah sorry I wasn't clear - if you have all the underlying bets grouped by strategy then you can do whatever aggregation you want (e.g. performance over time). Given Betfair's pnl tracking at account level is pretty basic you might as well do it yourself anyway, for which customerStrategyRef is totally sufficient to look at performance by strategy at whatever granularity/aggregation level IMO. Besides, betfairs orders only persist for 90 days so you ought to write em to a file anyway, at which point self-aggr is the way to go. Same advantages of the field apply to bankroll management, e.g. computing your exposure and whatnot.

For that he needs to keep some sort of overall record and write it out to a file.

text: Yeah, important to mention that MSA predated the customerStrategyRef field and that nowadays Betfair want you to use that field if all you need to do is differentiate strategies. MSA has other use cases such as allowing multiple users e.g. traders

text: The GC is not keen on MSA because it can be abused to facilitate problem gambling and money laundering so BF are not that keen to give them out. text: Just wondering how you're all implementing tracking for each strategy? I am currently saving the bet IDs by strategyRef and combining with getAccountStatement settled bet calls to identify the gross P&L for each strategy and then pickling that as a dict for future analysis. Downside is that it's difficult to match up commission rates for net profit calcs, particularly where bets have been placed on Aus markets which have variable rates rather than my usual 2%.

On a different subject, I've just been pinging <http://api.betfair.com|api.betfair.com> from various Lightsail instances and am finding that eu-west-1 (Ireland) is approx 1ms faster than eu-west-2 (London). Geo location suggests the IP address is London. Have Betfair moved their servers to Ireland?

text: They seem to run some sort of software to ensure the ping time doesn't get below about 10 ms, which you can get either from London or Dublin. And 1 ms is within the margin of error

attachments.fallback: [May 18th, 2020 7:50 AM] maurice: It's in Dublin but all traffic to it is routed via Betfair's anti-DDoS service provided by Prolexic in London

text:
Hi everyone, does anyone know an equation for calculating cash out/green up, where you’ve already got matched bets on both side?
For instance, I have a back bet matched, and go to cash out but I only get a partial match on my lay, and the lay odds change.
What equation can I use to work out the optimal lay amount at the new odds?

elements.text:
Hi everyone, does anyone know an equation for calculating cash out/green up, where you’ve already got matched bets on both side?
For instance, I have a back bet matched, and go to cash out but I only get a partial match on my lay, and the lay odds change.
What equation can I use to work out the optimal lay amount at the new odds?

text: If you are worried about ms you are using the wrong language

text:
1. Determine if you need a back bet or a lay to green up a selection. You do that by calculating the back return and lay return (if backReturn > layReturn then you need a BACK, otherwise LAY)
2. To calculate the hedge stake: (backReturn - layReturn) / best back available OR if you need a LAY then it's (layReturn-backReturn) / best lay price

elements.text: Determine if you need a back bet or a lay to green up a selection. You do that by calculating the back return and lay return (if backReturn > layReturn then you need a BACK, otherwise LAY)
To calculate the hedge stake: (backReturn - layReturn) / best back available OR if you need a LAY then it's (layReturn-backReturn) / best lay price

text:
I don't think you should obsess about this but just to point out that:

• The round trip route to Betfair if you're based in Dublin is heavily asymmetric because your request is routed via London but the response comes straight back to you from Dublin
• In terms of getting your request to Betfair as soon as possible, the only thing that matters is the outbound time
• Therefore, if all you are doing is comparing the round trip time, you cannot really say anything about which data center is better in terms of getting your request to Betfair as soon as possible

elements.text: I don't think you should obsess about this but just to point out that:
The round trip route to Betfair if you're based in Dublin is heavily asymmetric because your request is routed via London but the response comes straight back to you from Dublin
In terms of getting your request to Betfair as soon as possible, the only thing that matters is the outbound time
Therefore, if all you are doing is comparing the round trip time, you cannot really say anything about which data center is better in terms of getting your request to Betfair as soon as possible
